title: J head, Buda, and bowden adapters

description.text: Collection of various adapters using the approximate footprint of a standard jhead mounting plate that I have been creating to take the struggle out of adapting various hotends to my 3d printers.  Sometimes you have a non-bowden jhead you want to try as a bowden hence all the caps. The ones with insert in the description use a McMaster Carr M6 heatset insert to accept an M6 pushlock fitting.  The ones with threaded in the description are for people wanting to thread the M6 pushlock in.  I haven't tried that version but included it in case someone wants to try it.  I use the heatset inserts and also make these out of aluminum.  Some of the caps are for my aluminum versions of the jhead mounting plate. Some of the caps slip over a pushlock fitting when I use a Bowden hotend.  Also there are 30mm fan mounting holes in the jhead adapter blocks.  The caps have a ledge that catches the jhead in the pocket as well as compressing it down to hold it firmly in place.  They do require some long 4mm bolts though. To use the jhead mounting blocks in a direct drive setup you will need a shim or plug depending on the extruder you are using.  Some of the Greg's Wade are flat bottom and some have a recess.  A shim is needed for the flat bottom extruders and a plug will be needed for the recessed bottom extruders.  Most of the pictures are of the aluminum variety but I have used this jhead pocket principal on plastic mounts for a couple years now. If you need anything changed let me know and I will be happy help.

description.text: Low poly art for your poly heart!

Printer:

CTC

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

0/5%

Notes: 3 shell

I added 3 plexiglas sides to keep the heat in my Solidoodle 3 to assist with ABS printing.  Very simple - 2 hooks, a knob, and a neodymium magnet superglued to the top.  I ended up using the knob only on the front piece.  
Cut three 13" x 13" square sheets of plastic - I recommend 1/4" thick if you're going out to get it, but it can be 1/8" or 3/16" or 3/8" if you have the scrap.  
Mount the two clips on the bottom at the corners (shown in photo), and glue a magnet to each near the top.  A 1/8" thick magnet and the clips will leave about 1/8" gap all around, plenty for the various screws and rivets on the Solidoodle.  If you're using a Solidoodle 2, you'll need to reduce the size to fit, but the clips should work as-is.  
To remove, simply lift up the plexiglas - the magnet slides easier than it pulls off - and then pick off the sheet.

Printed in ABS with 10% fill (there is no strain on this).  Copy on your print bed and print them all in one go.  Six of the clips and either one or three knobs, depending on your preference (I used one for the front and none on the sides).  I recommend you rotate the knob to print the large end on the bed.  
Mount the clips at the lower corners and the knob below the magnet.  For the sides, I superglued the magnets 1/3 of the way, nearer the front, to clear my handles.  
Tap the knob for 4-40 or M3 (I used 6-32 because it was what I had, but that's about the limit)

comments.text: is there a significant heat gain with open top?
comments.author: cieszyn

comments.text: Yes compared to an open printer.  The main result is that your bed heats up quicker and the temperature remains higher and more stable within the printer, and the prints come out better.  Drafts through your printer can make a big difference.  I don't enclose the top because then I would need active temperature control to keep it from getting too hot.  I have only printed ABS since I got the printer so I can't speak for PLA.

This Sample Spool, is made of 3 parts. Two side flanges, and a single hub. However, the hub is unique. A large #3 can is needed to make the hub. I used a large can of Bush Pinto Beans.
Cut around the top part of the can about 40mm down from the top of the can. Then attach to the two side flanges using whatever method works, for you. I used pop rivets.

This is an idea whose value is probably more to stimulate you to think about the extraordinary range of practical uses to which 3D printing can be put. It's unlikely too many of you reading this will have precisely the same equipment to put together...  
This is a base to link an optical finder and a laser distance measuring device - and place them on a tripod. (Essential if you are doing DIY surveying!). The laser measurement device and finder are catalogue items. The tripod mount is separate from the base so you can tailor it to whatever tripod you may have at hand. All the design files are provided in a number of formats so you can modify them to your heart's content.

This couples an Orion 6x30 finder scope (http://www.amazon.com/camera-photo/dp/B0000XMVCM) and a generic laser distance measurement tool (in this case a Sndway SW-70). Rhino3D and STEP model files are provided. For amusement, the last 2 photos are totally OT, but shows the ray tracing software modelling the optics of the finder... The wonders of modern software tools ;-).
For the Hacker Chess project! more info at http://hackerchess.com

remixed_from.author: mithumor
remixed_from.title: Servo Gimbal for the Moebius Action Cam

description.text:
I've got inspired by the simple gimbal for Moebius action cam. I realized I need to change just one holder for the upper servo and I'll be able to mount it on the ceiling outside my house.
Now with simple arduino code to drive 2 servos, powered directly from TP-Link MR3020, I have remote camera surveillance with the ability to move the cam in all relevant angles.
It's easy to print - I just had to modify the middle connector and re-inforce it a bit.
To put it together, one needs to glue the original servo handle (the long one) to the appropriate part (both the middle connector and the camera holder) and prepare some zip-ties to tie the camera in 2 places.
Unfortunately, it was too foggy outside to make a picture and I'll not come back sooner than in a year :(

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Hesine i3 DIY kit

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm first layer, .2mm the rest

Infill:

20%

Notes: Quite easy to print, no need for special settings.

Glueing You need to glue the servo handles to the parts. The glue does not have to be too strong as the main force will be provided by the screw between the servo and the handle.
I used cheap 2-part resin with no problem. Screw in the servos Mount the 9-gram servos using the 2 provided mini-screws. Mount the base to the final place Mount the base unit to the final place before the assembly of the rest of the gimbal - the 9g servos are quite delicate and can be easily broken.
Window Handle I had to replace.  Suppose it could work for screen door as well.

My wife and I were given an antique chest with an old lock, but no key. I realized it needed a type of skeleton key, and what better way to create a custom out-of-date key than a 3D printer? I probed the lock with a small allen wrench and calipers to figure out where the notches needed to go. I printed a prototype key and was amazed that it worked on the first try. I tweaked the sizes a touch to make the fit smoother, made it pretty and printed the one you see here. Total time from measuring to trying the first key was about an hour. 
I doubt this particular key will fit anyone else's lock, but I've included my OpenSCAD file, which you can modify to fit your desired key dimensions if you have a need. I'm quite impressed that PLA is plenty strong enough to open and close this lock (it has a stiff spring). And the best part is, if I ever do break it, I can print a replacement in about half an hour.

comments.text:
The printing direction seems problematic. If you break the key, the remained part will stay within a keyhole and clog the hole. And we all know that the weakest direction is the Z direction.
Although aesthetically the upright direction is prettier, it'll have better strength when printed on its side.
comments.author: inornate

comments.text: You're welcome to try it that way, but cylinders don't tend to print well sideways. Also, in my experience, if you have the temperature well calibrated there is almost no difference in strength between the X-Y and Z directions. This is working great for me.

Looking for a good Math/Science Project for your young Engineer? This is a 3D printed funnel with four different size nozzles you can use to test the relationship between the time it takes sand to flow through the funnel and the size of the hole. My daughter's hypothesis was that the time would have a non-linear relationship to the area of the hole. Do you think she was right?

Printer:

BQ Witbox

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: This is a pretty straightforward print. Prints nicely on a PRINTinZ Plate.
https://www.printinz.com/printinz-3d-printer-plates/

Test Method The largest nozzle is the same size as the hole in the funnel. This was done for consistency between tests. Use clean, dry sand. It's a good idea to run it through a screen to make sure there are no big pieces of anything in it. Hold a finger over the opening and pour in the sand. Use a straight edge to level off the top. Start a timer as you remove your finger and hold the funnel level and steady. Record the time to empty it. Do at least three trials at each nozzle size and average them. Make a plot of time in seconds against the nozzle diameters ( or areas). The diameters were chosen to give you a hole area of about:
1.0 in sq
0.75 in sq
0.50 in sq
0.25 in sq

title: Eigenharp Tau to Manfrotto Quick Release Adapter

description.text:
After only 48 hours of owning an Eigenharp Tau, it has become obvious that my old man neck and arthritic shoulders are incompatible with the Tau neck strap.  I want to stand to play, so I decided that I needed to find something to hold the Tau for me.  
Using a CAD program and a 3D printer, I've created a Tau to Manfrotto Quick Release Tripod adapter.  With the Manfrotto ball joint head on a standard photographic tripod, the Tau can be positioned perfectly and solidly in just about any position.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

low

Infill:

60%

Notes: I printed this thing fairly solid so that it is strong. I don't want to trust this expensive instrument to a weak plastic adapter

Installation steps:
  • Remove the existing quick release bracket for the Tau neck strap.
  • Acquire some longer replacement screws (M3 .5x20mm) and some washers.
  • Fit the adapter into the location of the original bracket and insert the screws/washers.
  • Fit the adapter into the tripod and tighten the friction lever. The lock lever will snap into place making a very secure mount.
    • You're done. The Eigenharp Tau can now be held at virtually any angle or height.

author: skytec27

title: Garden Statue - Boy with Goose 3D Scan

description.text: We have an old statue in our back yard that has been in my wife's family for generations. It stands about 2 feet high, and has a spout coming out of the gooses' beak that you can pipe water to for a fountain. It's been painted many times and the paint is thick and peeling, but it has lots of character. I decided to try to scan it and see if I could print it out in 3D. I think overall it was a good result for a first time effort. For comparison, a video of the 123d Catch rendering is available here: https://youtu.be/lATga58Yqdc

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes: For the small 60 mm white model, I used MadeSolid PET+ at 250C, 30mm speed but the small size didn't allow a lot of detail. For the larger 150mm print I scaled it 3X and used Arctic Silver PLA from Cubicity at 190C . I used the uploaded file with supports already generated for both prints.

123D Catch & Meshmixer I took 38 photographs of the statue in my back yard from every angle, with lots of overlap. I then used 123D Catch to stitch them together into a mesh. Then I imported it into Meshmixer to clean it up a bit and output an STL file of the statue by itself, and another of the statue with supports. The 2 files are pretty huge, but my efforts to reduce their size resulted in too much loss of detail.

A bit of a specialised item here. A double rail chair for use with bar rail, for making check rails. My 7 1/4g garden railway is built with 20mm by 10mm flat bar. I use moulded plastic chairs from PNP Railways here in the UK. These are excellent, however PNP only make single slot chairs, not double. I needed check rails on two curves and some points. I therefore designed these to match the PNP chairs. One has a 10mm gap between rails, and the other has an 8mm gap. I designed them for use with No.4 stainless chipboard screws. One slot is higher than the other, and this is for the inner rail I printed mine in PLA with 25% infill. So far I have had no failures, and one part of the track runs across my gravel driveway. I run over this every day with my 4x4 pickup!
I use them every other sleeper on the curves.

comments.text: We have a similar setup at Train Mountain only we use them for our signal system to make insulated joints.  A block on each side of the rail with a spacer in the rail gap.  I would be interested how they hold with the UV rays outdoors.  Looks good.  Russ
comments.author: ChiloquinRuss

comments.text: Hi Russ. Yes i will be interested to see how they last with UV rays. I did wonder about dipping them in a UV protective varnish. I would think that we do not get quite as much sun here though. I deal with signalling at our club track. I am experimenting with 3D printed parts for our track circuiting as well. I have already installed a number of printed parts for the points interlock reed switches. As these are under covers, the UV problem should not arise. Cheers, Peter
comments.author: ChiloquinRuss

comments.text: UV is a big issue here, we are at 4300 feet and not much in the way of cloudy days.  We use recycled plastic ties (SLEEPERS) and when we get them they are almost pitch black but after two or three seasons they are a light concrete gray!  Good luck with your chair project it looks very promising!  Russ

If you succeeded to print a planetary gear model which is that smooth that you can turn it in overdrive, then you can use this part to turn it with a drill. The original planetary gear model reduces speed by 1:4 per stage. So in overdrive it spins 4 times per stage per revolution. So with two stages, one turn will rotate the other end 16 times. So if you spin it with a drill with like 1000 rpm you will end up with 16.000 rpm!

  • Note that this only fits on 200% scale printed planetary gear models!

  • If you try to use this with a drill, do so at your own risk and be very careful, since there is a big chance your planetary gear model will explode because of the RPM's.
    • For the grins i left some teeth of the original tool which i used for this sticking out of the back.

This is a 3d printable version of a folding tablet stand. Its visual/style borrows heavily from the Satechi R1 brand tablet stand design but requires various parts and some assembly to achieve this look while having some strength. Assembly is somewhat simple. The components are comprised of a "main" piece and a plate or gasket for strength. The approach is to glue the "plates" or "gaskets" to the "main" pieces in the appropriate spot to assemble the main components. These completed components are then assembled/fastened together with printed "Pins" and covered with the printed chamfered end caps. Components to build
-Base
base top
60 cents in nickels
coin holder
base bottom
large hinge
large gasket 3
-Arm
main arm
arm plate
small gasket 1
small gasket 2
large gasket 1
large gasket 2
-TabletHolder
holder plate
holder
holder plate
small hinge
small gasket 3 The gaskets are mainly for the benefit of the main arm hinges allowing it to be printed flat -in this orientation the hinge rings would not be strong enough so the gaskets are glued inside. Fragile part - Care must be taken when placing the gaskets in the main arm as it is easy to break the arm hinge loops if the fit is too tight. Make sure the gaskets insert with ease and let the glue hold them in place. Once the gaskets are in place things will be strong enough so that you can have some tension on the fastening pins so hinges are not loose. Insert the large and small pins to attach the arm component to the base and holder components. These (pins) print in halves so that you can get a clean cylinder. Glue the halves together and press them into place to complete the assembly. The pins should have a tight fit or the hinge may not hold the weight of the tablet - I did some minimal sanding and used a vice to slowly press the pins into place. Once even I glued on the end caps. The end caps are for looks but can also help tight the hinge depending on how you apply to glue. Assembly guidance

I watched a YouTube video review of the iPad Pro that demonstrated the tablet on the Satechi R1 tablet stand.   I looked up pics of the stand on Google... I considered how to replicate the look and function for "FDM" printing in plastic (ABS).... and the weight of the tablet ...which brought me to the use of embedded coins.  12 pennies worked well for iPad mini but felt "iffy" for iPad Air so I used 60 cents in nickels.  The stand size regardless of weight in the base is too small to support an iPad Pro.  
"It worked out".  In the end the main arm is a bit "springy", which I can correct by making the main arm thicker( 4 mm vs 2 ), but in use, it hasn't been as big a deal I was first worried upon realization.

Sometimes it's easier to design and fabricate a replacement part than to search for one to purchase. This was the case for my old disposer splash guard, also known as sink baffle or rubber cover. It requires a strong flexible material like Ninja SemiFlex (TPE).
If your disposer has an opening of 77mm and shoulder diameter of 85mm, this will fit perfectly.

Printer Brand:

Airwolf 3D

Printer:

AW3D HD

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: Best to use Ninja SemiFlex (TPE).

The usual trimming + hole punching + slit cutting The function of the part calls for axial slits to create a flexible aperture. I cut four slits, each extending to holes punched about halfway up. You can cut higher to create a larger maximum aperture (flexible opening for larger stuff to pass through when pushed).

Circular sweep object The measured collar opening and shoulder clearances along with a noticeable taper dictated the rim bead design. Height of rim bead was guesstimated at 5mm for adequate strength. The 60-degree rise is super easy for FDM printing. The thickness of 1mm eliminates Z-hop of printer head, allowing for a continuous bead after the rim is printed.

description.text: This is a 5" take-up reel for 1/2" video tape.  I was surprised to find there wasn't one here already, so here you are.   These are getting hard to find (I couldn't find any on Ebay, so I had to make one).

Print the file HalfInchReel.stl.  This prints the base half of the reel including the hub.  If you're running this horizontally, you don't really need the other half.  For a complete reel, next print HalfInchReelTop.stl.  Then glue the two pieces together, making sure the tape threading notches in the hub line up.  
The scad source is provided for your modding pleasure.  If you want to print a small sample to test the calibration of the critical central part, set the variable "basediameter" to 50.  The source can also be easily modified to make a 7" reel, or a reel for 1/4" audio tape.

comments.text: I wonder how difficult it would be to remix this into a 7" 1/4" R2R take up reel? I just bought an Akai GX 77 and the reels are expensive as hell. Could be a good winter project. Thanks for posting.
comments.author: PseudoShooter

comments.text: That's trivial to do.  Just change basediameter to whatever 7" is in mm.and hubheight to 1/4" (in mm.).  Everything is parameterized.  Unless you have a deck with wide NAB hubs this should work just fine.   Most 1/4" audio decks, including the GX-77 use the same standard cine spindle that 1/2" video does.
comments.author: PseudoShooter

comments.text: Great!
comments.author: Michele31415

comments.text:
There were many manufacturers of 1/2" open reel video recorders back in the 60's. Sony and Ampex were perhaps the two biggest ones. I have a Sony AV-3650. I created this take-up reel when I couldn't find one anywhere. Open reel video was pretty quickly killed off with the advent of VHS, Beta and 3/4" U-Matic.
"Can you use 1/2" video tape for multi-track audio, or does the spool have different mounting holes?"
I guess it depends on the audio recorder. If it doesn't use NAB hubs, then it will in all probability use a standard cine spindle like this one. Whether video tape works on an audio recorder also depends. Generally, I'd guess probably not, though Akai did make a multi-track audio recorder that used their VK-30 video cassettes.
comments.author: Michele31415

comments.text:
I'm surprised to find someone that actually owns a reel of 1/2" video tape. That was used, what, in the late 60's by Sony as an affordable B&W consumer product, and had died out by 1970?
Can you use 1/2" video tape for multi-track audio, or does the spool have different mounting holes?
comments.author: sfinktah

comments.text: Actually, open reel video tape was used by everybody before the advent of VHS and Beta - there was just no alternative.  Home/educational/industrial users typically used 1/2", and TV studios used 2", or later 1".  Of course today it's just a collector's item mainly useful to people who restore these ancient machines.

remixed_from.author: maso27
remixed_from.title: M3 T-Nut for OpenBuilds V-Slot Extrusion (Customizable)

description.text:
This is almost a full redesign of the X-Carve CNC from Inventables (https://www.inventables.com/technologies/x-carve) that uses only printed parts, off-the shelf components and usual V-Slot (not Makerslide or anything special). It should use the same software and have similar capabilities. Apart from the printed parts and easily available parts like bolts and nuts, you will need:
20x20 V-Slot rail - two pieces, length as desired for the X axis;
40x40 from the 20 series (or two 20x40) V-Slot rail - length as desired for the X axis, exactly the same as above;
20x40 V-Slot rail - two pieces, length as desired for the Y axis;
688Z bearings for XY wheels - MANY (number of wheels*2);
604Z bearings for Z carriage wheels - 8;
NEMA17 stepper motors - 4 (two for the X axis, one for Y and one for Z);
5 mm shaft pulleys - 4 (two for the X axis, one for Y and one for Z);
8 mm shaft pulleys - 2 (for Z axis);
ACME leadscrew and a nut for it - 1 (you can also use a simple M8 threaded rod if you edit the design, too);
Timing belt - 10 cm longer than your X and Y rails are. Should match your pulleys;
Looped timing belt - must match your pulleys and Z-axis motor plate. For an understanding of the assembly, please look at the original X-Carve drawings (attached here for convenience), compare them to the pictures above and the part names. They should be self-descriptive. The Z carriage mechanism of mine is different, so see notes below. UPDATE #1:
  • Made the Z axis carriage more stable, now it does not wobble. Now the spindle is attached via four M4 screws arranged as a square 35x35 mm.
  • Added a mount for DC and BLDC motors I am planning to test as spindles (see pics)
    • UPDATE #2:
  • Added a new type of carriage
    fot HIWIN rails, which five significantly nore stiffness;
  • Added Dremel 300 and round router mount for both types of carriages
  • Added tighter Z wheels and appropriate inner spacers for them
  • Added drag chain and belt holders
  • Machine operational, frst tests are being made! In the pics there is a creeper head milled out of styrofoam using VISUALCADCAM.
  • Added laser line holders!
  • First test video!
    https://youtu.be/rsAjviPOO2U
    Here the machine is making its own wasteboard.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.5 nozzle 0.2 layer

Notes: Used ABS for all parts including wheels. For the wheels you can also use Flexi or Nylon.
  • IMPORTANT *
    When printing the wheels set your layer start point (in slicer) to RANDOM, this will save you from the 'bump' on one side of the wheels that will cause trouble in movement!

Z Axis Carriage When everything is ready, you need to decide on what your Z axis carriage will be. I have tried two options: roller carriage like on te X-carve and a carriage based on HIWIN rails. Eventually, the roller carriage appeared to put too much load on the wheels and tended to bend. You can go with this option if you have a light-duty application (or redesign the carriage to make it longer and beefier). First, you need to cut two sides of the round ACME nut as shown in the pics to fit it into the Z carriage. Tap M3 or M4 thread int he holes, insert into the carriage and fix with screws from the other side. For the Roller carriage: Next, assemble the wheels: choose between normal 20 mm wheels and the tighter ones (my attempt to deal with the wobble that failed). Use the Z axis wheel spacer set and Z axis inner wheel spacers in the following order (starting from the screw's head):
  • smallest spacer to decouple the head from the moving parts
  • 604Z bearing no. 1
  • Inner wheel spacer
  • The wheel itself
  • 604Z bearing no. 2
  • The biggest spacer from set
  • OPTIONAL If your carriage goes too tight, this may be due to incorrect distance between wheel centers and you need to put the middle spacer from the set to eliminate this.
  • Carriage
  • M4 Nylock nut
    Repeat four times for four wheels.
    • Then, roll your carriage on the V-slot rail and insert the ACME rod. Turn to move further. The HIWIN variant: Get two HIWIN MGNR 9H rails and MGN9C carriages. Cut the rails if your Z axis is too small for them. Put the rails into the V-slot on two sides (YES THEY SHOULD GO INTO THE APERTURE A BIT) and add a needed amount of M3 T-nuts for V-slot (easily found on Thingiverse, see Remix Sources) to hold the M3 screws in place.
    Fix the HIWIN carriages to the printed one with eight M3 screws.
    Do not tighten the rails yet. First, roll the carriage onto them, ensure smooth movement and then tighten everything. Both options:
    After your carriage is in place, use two screws and a 688Z bearing to mount the pillow block. Tool Mount The two carriages have different mounting holes: 35x35 for the roller variant and 35x50 for the HIWIN variant. Use appropriate tool holders from the files given or design your own. The laser line holder is designed to hold two 12 mm diameter laser lines at 120 degrees to each other. See pic below to get an idea of how this is made: Laser line holders are mounted between the tool mount and the carriage like this, the spacing between should be 2 mm. The individual line holders are mounted on the sides, right in the 2 mm space.

A simple display case for the Raspberry Pi 2 & 3 Model B. I used a 3.5inch touchscreen LCD, which is purchased from ebay. Link and guide is listed below. The micro SD card is accessible from outside. A special feature is, that it is held in place, even when the spring loaded mechanism of the sd slot fails (which happened here). The raspi is entirely passive cooled. I have not used a heat sink or a fan. Do not print assembly.stl. I have three different top parts. I only used and printed that width the display. I used some weak glue to bind the parts together.

description.header: In case you need some changes to the model to fit your Display, there is a customizer
description.text:
If this is not enough for you, feel free to send me a message :) User-specified models:
raspiBplusCase_top_differentCutout.stl
raspiBplusCase_top_extraTall.stl

display is from ebay guide to bring it to life (I used the raspbian image)

title: Tablet stand that mounts on Corsair keyboards (K65, K70, K95 etc)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Tablet stand for Corsair keyboards (K65, K70, K95 etc)
Made a set of stands that fit under and over the standard Corsair gaming keyboards.  They fit snugly (not tight) and provide stable mounting.  I added some 10mm square holes to allow the two pieces to be connected.  I don't find it's needed but it's there if you want to use it.  Also included a default 10mm crossbar (263mm long) that should work for 10" tablets.   You can easily make longer or shorter crossbars in most slicers, and an adapter is included to link several crossbars together if your printer can't do your required length in once piece.  This will allow you to print several shorter lengths and join them together.
A small bit of rubber or foam can be added to the bottom of the tablet area to prevent sliding.
A set of bigger stands is also included.  These will hang the tablet over the keyboard a bit.  I didn't bevel out the front holder on these yet, maybe in the future.

This is a pendant made with the Bassnectar logo. I looked around for one to print myself but couldn't find what I was looking for, so here's my iteration of a 3D printable Bassnectar pendant to share with you all. Enjoy! I did make this file a non-commercial download since this is Lorin's logo. If you want to buy Bassnectar jewelry, you can visit the Bassnectar online store where they've got a ton of cool gear. (https://store.bassnectar.net/collections/jewelry) UPDATE:
I did remove the original (bassnectar.stl) and uploaded a revised version (bassnectar_pendant.stl) that has a slightly adjusted hole to allow for the simple necklace string I have on hand here, to feed through easier.
